fields.value: Improving Prison Classification Procedures in Vermont:  Applying an Interaction Model, 1983-1985

dsDescriptionValue.value: The purpose of this data collection was to develop and test  an interactive model for classifying prisoners. The model includes  person variables, environmental or situation variables, and  prison-environmental interaction variables in order to study the  interactions between individuals and their environments and to predict  offender behaviors such as escape, misconduct, and violence. The model  was designed to enhance the predictive validity of the National  Institute of Corrections' classification system that was being used in  Vermont prisons. Included are scores from the National Institute of  Corrections' custody classification and reclassification instruments,  scores from a needs assessment, sentencing information, and characteristics of the prison in which the inmate was housed.

topicClassValue.value: ICPSR XVII.E. Social Institutions and Behavior, Crime and the Criminal Justice System

distributorAffiliation.value: Institute for Social Research, University of Michigan

value: records of the Vermont State Department of Corrections
Inmates of state correctional facilities in Vermont.

fields.value: The sample consists of 982 inmates incarcerated in Vermont  state correctional facilities who had at least 30 days to serve in  their sentences. Median age of the sample was 25 years with a range of  15 to 69 years. Males constituted 97.5 percent of the sample and had a  median minimum sentence of one year and a median maximum of three years.
